Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Fleck \Fleck\, n. A flake; also, a lock, as of wool. [Obs.] --J. Martin. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Fleck \Fleck\, n. [Cf. Icel. flekkr; akin to Sw. fl["a]ck, D. vlek, G. fleck, and perh. to E. flitch.] A spot; a streak; a speckle. ``A sunny fleck.'' --Longfellow. [1913 Webster]
Life is dashed with flecks of sin. --tennyson. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Fleck \Fleck\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Flecked}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Flecking}.] [Cf. Icel. flekka, Sw. fl["a]cka, D. vlekken, vlakken, G. flecken. See {Fleck}, n.] To spot; to streak or stripe; to variegate; to dapple. [1913 Webster]
Both flecked with white, the true Arcadian strain. --Dryden. [1913 Webster]
A bird, a cloud, flecking the sunny air. --Trench. [1913 Webster]

fleck n 1: a small fragment of something broken off from the whole; "a bit of rock caught him in the eye" [syn: {bit}, {chip}, {flake}, {scrap}] 2: a small contrasting part of something; "a bald spot"; "a leopard's spots"; "a patch of clouds"; "patches of thin ice"; "a fleck of red" [syn: {spot}, {speckle}, {dapple}, {patch}, {maculation}] v : make a spot or mark onto; "The wine spotted the tablecloth" [syn: {spot}, {blob}, {blot}]
